deliberation: Identified 'rousing a destructive wind against Babylon' (רוּחַ מַשְׁחִית) as metaphorical language for an invading, destructive force stirred up by God; Leb-qamai is a cryptogram, not figurative. No other clear figures.

instances.english_text: a destructive wind
target: the hostile force God sends against Babylon
ground: suddenness, irresistibility, wide-ranging devastation
overwhelming destructive impact
danger/destruction
posture: negative portrayal of the invasion as a divinely stirred natural catastrophe
instances.explanation: The 'wind' represents the invading force God stirs up against Babylon, likening the attackers to a destructive gale that sweeps through and devastates.

deliberation: The sending of 'strangers' is literal, but 'they shall winnow her' (וְזֵר֔וּהָ) applies an agricultural process to Babylon as if she were grain; 'empty/strip her land' continues same image. Treated as one extended agricultural metaphor.

instances.english_text: and they shall winnow her, and they shall strip her land bare
ground: separating out and removing what is desired, leaving emptiness and waste
thorough removal and dispersal
loss/devastation
posture: depicts Babylon as passively processed and exhausted by invaders
instances.explanation: Invading nations are portrayed as farmers winnowing grain, with Babylon as the grain that is sifted and its land emptied, emphasizing total plundering and dispersal.

deliberation: The verse issues literal military commands (archer, bow, coat of mail, young men, army). 'Devote to destruction' (הַחֲרִימוּ) is a technical term rather than a figurative image here. I see no distinct metaphor, simile, or personification beyond standard war language.
Describes literal casualties ('slain in the land of Chaldea, pierced through in her streets'). The wording is vivid but not figurative; no metaphor or simile is used.

Identified covenantal metaphor: Israel/Judah described as not being 'widowed' from their God, implying prior imagery of God as husband; 'land filled with guilt' is conceptual but conventional. One clear metaphor.

instances.english_text: For Israel and Judah were not bereft [widowed] of their God
vehicle: a woman who is (or is not) a widow
ground: ongoing belonging and support despite catastrophe; not permanently abandoned
relational fidelity and continued bond
covenant loyalty
posture: reassuring depiction of God’s continuing commitment despite judgment
instances.explanation: Israel and Judah are portrayed as a wife who has not actually become a widow, implying that God remains their living husband and covenant partner.

deliberation: Commands to flee and save one’s life and references to 'time of vengeance' and 'repayment' are standard judicial language. Considered whether 'perish for her iniquity' is metaphorical but here it describes literal perishing because of Babylon’s sins. No distinct figurative image.

This verse uses a sustained metaphor: Babylon as a golden cup in God’s hand whose wine makes the nations drunk and mad. The 'drinking' and 'madness' unfold that image; I treat it as one extended metaphor.

instances.hebrew_text: כּוֹס־זָהָ֤ב בָּבֶל֙ בְּיַד־יְהוָ֔ה מְשַׁכֶּ֖רֶת כׇּל־הָאָ֑רֶץ מִיֵּינָהּ֙ שָׁת֣וּ גוֹיִ֔ם עַל־כֵּ֖ן יִתְהֹלְל֥וּ גוֹיִֽם
instances.english_text: Babylon was a golden cup in GOD’s hand, it made the whole earth drunk; the nations drank of her wine—therefore the nations are mad
target: Babylon’s imperial influence and the nations she affects
vehicle: a golden cup of intoxicating wine held by God
luxury drinking vessel and its wine
ground: Babylon as an attractive but dangerous instrument in God’s hand that intoxicates and deranges many nations
harmful, intoxicating influence serving divine purposes
judgment and moral corruption
posture: negative, depicting Babylon as both precious and deadly, ultimately under God’s control
instances.explanation: Babylon’s power is depicted as a golden cup whose wine represents her intoxicating, corrupting influence on the nations, used by God to bring them into a mad stupor of judgment.

deliberation: Babylon’s 'falling' could be literal, but 'shattered' plus 'balm for her pain... perhaps she may be healed' applies the language of bodily injury and medical treatment to the city’s political collapse. I treat this as one medical metaphor for her downfall.

instances.hebrew_text: פִּתְאֹ֛ם נָפְלָ֥ה בָבֶ֖ל וַתִּשָּׁבֵ֑ר ... קְח֤וּ צֳרִי֙ לְמַכְאוֹבָ֔הּ אוּלַ֖י תֵּרָפֵֽא
instances.english_text: Suddenly Babylon has fallen and is shattered; ... Get balm for her wounds: Perhaps she can be healed
vehicle: a human body that has fallen, been shattered, and needs balm for wounds
ground: severe, perhaps irreparable damage needing healing; fragility under catastrophe
incurability of Babylon’s condition
judgment as sickness
posture: ironically proposes healing for a hopelessly shattered Babylon, underscoring her doom
instances.explanation: Babylon’s collapse is pictured as a person’s catastrophic injury requiring balm and healing, highlighting both the severity and the likely incurability of her condition.

deliberation: The verse continues the medical metaphor ('We tried to heal Babylon, but she was not healed') and adds hyperbolic vertical imagery ('her judgment reaches to heaven, lifted up to the skies'). I treat these as two distinct figures.

instances.english_text: We tried to cure Babylon but she was incurable
vehicle: medical treatment and healing of a sick person
ground: application of remedies that fail to produce recovery; the condition is beyond cure
hopelessness of Babylon’s situation
irreversible judgment
posture: despairing recognition that Babylon’s illness (guilt/judgment) cannot be reversed
instances.explanation: Efforts to 'heal' Babylon are depicted as failed medical treatment, emphasizing that the city’s plight is terminal.

instances.english_text: For her punishment reaches to heaven, it is as high as the sky
vehicle: height reaching up to heaven and the skies
ground: enormous magnitude and visibility; beyond ordinary measure
greatness and notoriety of her judgment
severity/excess
posture: emphatic exaggeration to stress just how great Babylon’s punishment is
instances.explanation: The punishment (or guilt) of Babylon is said to reach up to heaven, an exaggerated image highlighting its immense magnitude and seriousness.

deliberation: God 'brings out' or 'proclaims' their righteousness; this is standard legal-vindication language rather than a crafted metaphor in context. No prominent, distinct figurative expression beyond normal judicial idiom.

The war-preparation commands are literal. 'He has roused the spirit of the kings of Media' uses רוּחַ for inner disposition, but this is conventional. 'Vengeance of His temple' treats the temple as shorthand for what was done to it and to the worshipers; I classify that as metonymy.

instances.english_text: For this is GOD’s vengeance, vengeance for His temple
target: God’s vengeance for wrongs done to His people and worship
ground: the temple stands for the whole sphere of God’s presence and worship that Babylon violated
using the sanctuary as shorthand for the entire covenant relationship offended
representative part-whole relation
posture: frames Babylon’s punishment as payback specifically for desecrating God’s sanctuary
instances.explanation: The 'vengeance of His temple' uses the temple as a representative part for the whole covenant relationship and worship life that Babylon attacked, focusing divine retribution on that offense.

deliberation: All elements (standard, walls, watch, ambush) are literal military imagery. 'Planned and performed' is straightforward; nothing clearly figurative beyond normal martial description.

Babylon literally dwellt by many waters (Euphrates and canals) and possessed great stores; 'your end has come, the measure of your unjust gain' is evaluative but not an independent image. I do not treat these as distinct figurative devices here.
Identified a clear simile: filling Babylon with enemies 'like locusts', a common image for innumerable invaders. The shout against her follows from that swarm imagery.

instances.english_text: I will fill you with men like a locust swarm
ground: overwhelming numbers, rapid devastating consumption, inescapability
multitude and destructive impact
threat/destruction
posture: intensely negative, portraying the invaders as a devouring plague upon Babylon
instances.explanation: The attackers are compared to a locust swarm to stress their vast numbers and their consuming, inescapable devastation of Babylon.

deliberation: The verse is a creation formula. 'Stretched out the skies' (נָטָה שָׁמַיִם) anthropomorphically portrays God as stretching the heavens like a fabric or tent; this is a standard metaphor, but still figurative.

instances.english_text: And with understanding [He] stretched out the skies
target: God’s act of arranging the heavens
vehicle: stretching out fabric or a tent
ground: deliberate arrangement and extension over a wide area
ordered, skilled shaping of the cosmos
wisdom and power in creation
posture: elevates God as a wise craftsman of the universe
instances.explanation: God’s creation of the heavens is likened to stretching out a fabric or tent, emphasizing His skillful, intentional ordering of the sky.

deliberation: The description of waters, vapors, lightning is largely literal meteorology under divine command. 'He brings out the wind from His storehouses/treasuries' is a metaphor, picturing winds as stored goods God releases.

instances.english_text: And [He] brings forth wind from His treasuries
target: origin and timing of the wind
vehicle: storage rooms of a great house
ground: having resources stored and dispensing them at will
sovereign management and distribution
control/provision
posture: stresses God’s sovereign management of natural forces as if they were stored treasures
instances.explanation: Winds are portrayed as if kept in God’s 'treasuries' and released by Him, underscoring His sovereign, almost royal control over nature.

deliberation: The verse contrasts human ignorance with lifeless idols. 'Every man is brutish (נִבְעַר) without knowledge' likens people to cattle/beasts in their stupidity—a metaphorical usage. The shame of the goldsmith is literal consequence.

instances.english_text: Every mortal is proved dull [brutish], without knowledge
vehicle: brutishness like that of an animal
ground: lack of rational insight, acting like unthinking beasts
stupidity and moral insensitivity
folly/irrationality
posture: strongly disparaging portrayal of idolaters as no better than animals in understanding
instances.explanation: People who make and trust idols are described as 'brutish,' i.e., like irrational beasts, to highlight their folly and lack of true knowledge.

deliberation: Idols are called 'hebel' (vanity/breath) and 'a work of mockeries'. 'Hebel' metaphorically equates them with vapor or nothingness; this is a standard prophetic metaphor for worthlessness.

instances.english_text: They are delusion [vanity], a work of mockery
target: idols and the practice of idol-making
ground: lack of solidity, permanence, or real power; emptiness
futility and unreliability of idols
worthlessness
posture: contemptuous dismissal of idols as insubstantial and deceptive
instances.explanation: Idols are likened to vapor or breath to stress their utter insubstantiality and unreliability as gods.

deliberation: Contrasts lifeless idols with Israel’s God. Two metaphors: (1) 'Portion of Jacob' presents God as Jacob’s allotted share/inheritance; (2) 'rod of His inheritance' presents Israel as God’s scepter or ruling staff. Both are distinct figurative expressions.

instances.english_text: Not like these is the Portion of Jacob
vehicle: a 'portion' or allotted share of an inheritance
ground: exclusive, valued possession belonging to someone; source of sustenance and security
God as Israel’s true, sustaining inheritance
belonging/provision
posture: positive, intimate depiction of God as Israel’s true share as opposed to empty idols
instances.explanation: Calling God the 'Portion of Jacob' presents Him as Israel’s true allotted share and inheritance, in contrast to lifeless idols.

instances.english_text: and [Israel is] the rod of His inheritance
vehicle: a 'rod' or scepter associated with rule
ground: instrument of rule and representation of authority belonging to a king
Israel as an instrument and display of God’s kingship
authority/representation
posture: elevates Israel’s identity as God’s royal staff, highlighting their special status and function
instances.explanation: Israel is depicted as God’s 'rod' or scepter, symbolizing that they are His chosen instrument and visible emblem of His rule.

deliberation: This begins a sustained metaphor where the addressee (instrument of judgment) is God’s 'war club' with which He shatters nations and kingdoms. Although the destruction is literal, the identification of the nation with a hammer/club is figurative.

instances.hebrew_text: מַפֵּץ־אַתָּ֣ה לִ֔י כְּלֵ֖י מִלְחָמָ֑ה וְנִפַּצְתִּ֤י בְךָ֙ גּוֹיִ֔ם וְהִשְׁחַתִּ֥י בְךָ֖ מַמְלָכֽוֹת
instances.english_text: You are My war club, [My] weapons of battle; with you I clubbed nations, with you I destroyed kingdoms
target: the human instrument/nation God uses to judge others
vehicle: war club and weapons in a warrior’s hand
ground: being an instrument through which the wielder’s power is expressed; capacity to crush opponents
God’s use of this nation as His tool to shatter others
instrumentality/power
posture: initially exalts the addressee as God’s hammer, but in context sets up their own eventual judgment
instances.explanation: The unnamed power is likened to God’s war-hammer, emphasizing that its conquests are actually God’s work done through an instrument He wields.

deliberation: This verse elaborates the same 'war club' metaphor from v.20, listing targets (horse and rider, chariot and driver). No new figurative mapping beyond the already-established hammer imagery; so I do not count an additional distinct instance here.
Again extends the war-club metaphor (now applied to all classes of people). The figurative framework is unchanged from v.20; the pairs are literal groups. No new independent figure.
Continues the same hammer-of-God metaphor, specifying further social roles shattered. No separate metaphor or simile is introduced; it remains part of the v.20 image.
God’s promise to 'requite' Babylon for the evil done to Zion is standard judicial language. 'Before your eyes' is literal. No distinct metaphor or personification beyond normal retributive idiom.

Babylon is addressed as 'destroying mountain' that destroys the whole earth; then God will roll it from the rocks and make it a 'burnt mountain'. This uses mountain imagery metaphorically for the empire and its downfall.

instances.hebrew_text: הַ֤ר הַמַּשְׁחִית֙ ... הַמַּשְׁחִ֖ית אֶת־כׇּל־הָאָ֑רֶץ ... וְגִלְגַּלְתִּ֙יךָ֙ מִן־הַסְּלָעִ֔ים וּנְתַתִּ֖יךָ לְהַ֥ר שְׂרֵפָֽה
instances.english_text: O mountain of the destroyer, destroyer of the whole earth ... I will roll you down from the crags, and make you a burnt-out mountain
target: Babylonian empire in its power and its downfall
vehicle: a towering mountain that devastates and then becomes a burned-out mountain rolled from its crags
ground: height, solidity, and far-reaching impact, followed by sudden ruin and permanent defacement
Babylon’s dominant, destructive might and its total, fiery collapse
power and its undoing
posture: strongly condemnatory; Babylon is a dangerous peak God will topple and burn
instances.explanation: Babylon is portrayed as a 'destroying mountain' towering over and ravaging the earth, which God will roll down and leave as a burned-out ruin.

deliberation: Speaks of no stone being taken from Babylon as cornerstone or foundation stone and of permanent desolation. These are literal building terms describing total ruin; no clear independent metaphor beyond standard prophetic hyperbole.
Military summons are literal, but 'bring up horses like bristling locusts' is an explicit simile likening the cavalry to a dense, bristling swarm.

instances.english_text: Bring up horses like swarming locusts
ground: innumerable, overwhelming numbers and movement, evoking dread and devastation
the overwhelming, devouring nature of the invading horsemen
threatening multitude
posture: depicts the attacking forces as a terrifying, devouring swarm
heightens fear of the coming onslaught
instances.explanation: The numerous horses are compared to a bristling locust swarm to convey their vast numbers and threatening advance on Babylon.

deliberation: Lists nations, kings, governors, and their lands assembled for war. Straightforward muster language; no overt metaphor, simile, or personification.

The earth 'quakes' could be literal, but 'writhes' (וַתָּחֹל) evokes a laboring woman; together they personify the land as reacting to God’s purpose. I treat this as personification of the land under judgment.

instances.english_text: Then the earth quakes and writhes
target: the land affected by Babylon’s fall
vehicle: a living body trembling and twisting in labor pains
ground: violent, involuntary reaction to intense pressure and pain
cosmic disturbance mirroring the severity of God’s judgment
agony/upheaval
posture: portrays the whole earth as agonizing in response to God’s plans against Babylon
instances.explanation: The land is depicted as a living being that trembles and writhes like a woman in labor, stressing how momentous and painful God’s judgment on Babylon is.

deliberation: The verse uses two clear metaphors: (1) 'their might is dried up' uses drought imagery for loss of courage; (2) 'they became women' uses gendered metaphor for losing warrior bravery. I treat these as two distinct expressions.

instances.english_text: Their might is dried up
vehicle: liquid drying up, perhaps a river or spring
ground: once-flowing strength now exhausted and gone; inability to act
complete depletion of power and morale
weakness/exhaustion
posture: depicts Babylon’s warriors as no longer having any vital strength
instances.explanation: Their courage and power are portrayed as a water source that has dried up, indicating complete depletion of strength.

instances.english_text: They become women
vehicle: women as stereotypically non-warrior, non-combatant figures in ancient context
ground: loss of martial courage and aggressiveness as defined by ancient male-warrior ideals
becoming timid and unable to fight
cowardice/weakness (in ANE idiom)
posture: derogatory in the ancient cultural frame, highlighting complete loss of warrior status
instances.explanation: By saying the warriors 'become women,' the text, in its ancient context, metaphorically declares that they have lost the courage and aggression expected of male fighters.

deliberation: Depicts literal messengers running to report the capture of the city. Vivid but straightforward narrative; no distinct metaphor or simile beyond normal description.
Describes fords seized, marshes burned, and warriors terrified. The imagery is military and topographical, not figurative in itself.

Here Babylon is called 'Daughter Babylon' and likened to a threshing floor being trodden; additionally, 'her harvest time' coming is a familiar metaphor for judgment. I treat (1) the simile 'like a threshing floor' and (2) the 'harvest' as judgment as two related but distinct figures.

instances.english_text: Fair Babylon is like a threshing floor ready to be trodden
target: Babylon in the moment before judgment
vehicle: a threshing floor about to be trodden
prepared surface where grain is trampled
ground: being positioned for imminent, forceful processing that separates grain from chaff
Babylon poised for destructive judgment
readiness for decisive action
posture: portrays Babylon as about to undergo a harsh, separating process at God’s hand
instances.explanation: Babylon is compared to a threshing floor about to be trodden, indicating she is poised for the harsh process of divine judgment.

instances.english_text: In a little while her harvesttime will come
ground: a set season when what has grown is finally cut down and gathered
moment when accumulated deeds yield consequences
reaping what is sown
posture: frames judgment as the inevitable harvest of Babylon’s actions
instances.explanation: Babylon’s day of judgment is metaphorically called her 'harvesttime,' the season when what has been sown is finally reaped.

deliberation: Speaking in Zion’s voice, the verse describes Nebuchadnezzar as devouring, swallowing 'like a dragon', filling his belly with delicacies, then setting the speaker down like an empty dish and rinsing. This is an extended devouring/monster metaphor, with an explicit simile 'like a dragon'. I focus on that simile as representative.

instances.english_text: He swallowed me like a dragon, he filled his belly with my dainties
vehicle: a dragon/sea monster ravenously swallowing prey and filling its belly
ground: rapacious consumption, using up the victim’s resources completely, leaving them empty
total exploitation and destruction of the victim
greed and brutality
posture: strongly accusatory and emotive, portraying the king as a monstrous devourer
instances.explanation: Nebuchadnezzar’s oppression of Zion is likened to a dragon swallowing prey and filling its belly, emphasizing his greedy, destructive consumption of her resources.

deliberation: The speaker calls for 'my violence and my flesh' (or 'loss') to be upon Babylon and 'my blood' upon the Chaldeans. 'My blood' is a metonymy for the life unjustly taken and the guilt of shedding it.

instances.english_text: And let my blood be upon the inhabitants of Chaldea
target: the guilt and responsibility for the harm done to Zion
ground: blood stands for the life wrongfully taken and the moral debt incurred
calling that guilt down upon the perpetrators
liability/retribution
posture: invokes a legal-curse formula demanding that the perpetrators bear the consequences of shed blood
instances.explanation: The phrase 'my blood be upon...' uses blood as a metonymy for the life taken and the guilt associated with its shedding, calling that guilt down on the Chaldeans.

deliberation: God will 'dry up her sea' and 'make her fountain dry'. This may refer to literal waters, but the imagery also functions metaphorically for removing Babylon’s life-sources and defenses. I treat this as one metaphorical portrayal of cutting off her vitality.

instances.english_text: I will dry up her sea and make her fountain run dry
target: Babylon’s sources of strength, wealth, and defense
vehicle: sea and spring being dried up
large body of water and its source disappearing
ground: removal of protective and life-giving resources, leaving vulnerability and death
cutting off Babylon’s life-blood and defenses
deprivation/ruin
posture: depicts God as decisively removing all that sustains Babylon
instances.explanation: Babylon’s key resources and defenses are portrayed as a 'sea' and 'spring' that God will dry up, symbolizing the loss of her sustaining power.

deliberation: Babylon becoming 'heaps, a den for jackals' can be literal ruin imagery, but 'an object of horror and hissing' (שַׁמָּה וּשְׁרֵקָה) is a set prophetic idiom for being mocked and derided. I treat that as one idiomatic figurative expression.

instances.english_text: a den for jackals, an object of horror and hissing
vehicle: desolate lair of wild animals and a spectacle that makes people hiss in scorn
ground: total abandonment, wild desolation, and being held up as a cautionary example of ruin
Babylon as a byword for desolation and scorn
disgrace/desolation
posture: deeply negative, depicting Babylon as both physically ruined and socially ridiculed
instances.explanation: Calling Babylon a 'den for jackals' and an object of 'horror and hissing' portrays her as a desolate ruin that onlookers mock and shudder at, a standard idiom for utter disgrace.

deliberation: Babylonians (likely revelers/warriors) are compared to lions and lion cubs in their roaring and growling. This is a double animal simile expressing their boisterous, predatory confidence.

instances.hebrew_text: יַחְדָּ֖ו כַּכְּפִרִ֣ים יִשְׁאָ֑גוּ נָעֲר֖וּ כְּגוֹרֵ֥י אֲרָיֽוֹת
instances.english_text: Like lions, they roar together, they growl like lion cubs
target: Babylonian leaders/warriors in their revelry or war-cry
vehicle: adult lions and lion cubs roaring and growling
ground: loud, fearsome, confident noise; predatory vigor
Babylonians’ boisterous self-assurance and ferocity
strength/ferocity
posture: initially grants them ferocious power, which in context will be overturned by judgment
instances.explanation: The Babylonians are likened to roaring lions and their cubs, highlighting their fierce, noisy confidence before their downfall.

deliberation: Two figures: (1) God makes them drunk so they 'rejoice'—drunkenness as metaphor for stupefying judgment; (2) 'they shall sleep an endless sleep and not wake' is a metaphor for death. These are distinct though related images.

instances.hebrew_text: בְּחֻמָּ֞ם אָשִׁ֣ית אֶת־מִשְׁתֵּיהֶ֗ם וְהִשְׁכַּרְתִּים֙ לְמַ֣עַן יַעֲלֹ֔זוּ
instances.english_text: When they are heated, I will set out their drink and get them drunk, that they may become hilarious
target: Babylon’s leaders and warriors under divine judgment
vehicle: people heated with desire then plied with drink until drunk
ground: losing self-control, becoming foolishly merry just before collapse or vulnerability
stupefaction and false security before disaster
deception/vulnerability
posture: ironically shows God luring them into a state of drunken carelessness as part of their judgment
instances.explanation: Their intoxication is orchestrated by God to make them blindly joyful and unguarded, a metaphor for how divine judgment stupefies them before their downfall.

instances.english_text: and then sleep an endless sleep, never to awake
target: the final fate of Babylon’s elites
ground: inactivity and unresponsiveness of sleep as an image for death’s permanence
death as irrevocable, unlike normal sleep
cessation of activity
posture: presents their death under God’s judgment as permanent, like a sleep from which there is no waking
instances.explanation: Their death is described as an 'endless sleep' to convey its finality and the impossibility of recovery from God’s judgment.

deliberation: Uses an explicit simile: people are brought down 'like lambs for slaughter, like rams and he-goats', likening doomed victims to sacrificial animals.

instances.english_text: I will bring them down like lambs for slaughter, like rams and he-goats
target: those to be destroyed in Babylon
vehicle: lambs, rams, and goats led to slaughter
ground: being helplessly led to inevitable death, without effective resistance
complete vulnerability before a determined slaughterer
doom/helplessness
posture: portrays the victims as defenseless sacrificial animals in God’s hands
instances.explanation: Those God will destroy are compared to sacrificial sheep and goats being led to slaughter, stressing their helplessness and the certainty of their death.

deliberation: Sheshach (cipher for Babylon) is said to be captured, 'the praise of the whole earth' seized, and to become a 'horror among the nations'. 'Praise of the whole earth' is a metaphorical epithet for Babylon’s former glory; I treat that as the main figure.

instances.english_text: The praise of the whole earth has been taken
vehicle: 'praise of the whole earth'—object universally praised
ground: being widely admired, envied, and celebrated across nations
Babylon’s erstwhile global prestige
glory/fame
posture: underscores the irony that one once universally admired is now captured and made a horror
instances.explanation: Babylon is called 'the praise of the whole earth,' portraying her as the object of worldwide admiration, which makes her present capture and disgrace more striking.

deliberation: The 'sea' rising over Babylon and covering her with roaring waves likely symbolizes the invading armies, a common prophetic metaphor; Babylon is personified as being submerged by this sea.

instances.hebrew_text: עָלָ֥ה עַל־בָּבֶ֖ל הַיָּ֑ם בַּהֲמ֥וֹן גַּלָּ֖יו נִכְסָֽתָה
instances.english_text: The sea has risen over Babylon; she is covered by its roaring waves
target: the overwhelming invasion and destruction of Babylon
vehicle: a sea with roaring waves inundating and covering a city
ground: overwhelming, inescapable, engulfing force; loud tumult
invading armies’ unstoppable advance and total coverage of the land
overrun/overwhelmed
posture: depicts Babylon as helplessly submerged under the flood of attackers
instances.explanation: The 'sea' represents the mass of invading forces that inundate Babylon like roaring waves, emphasizing the overwhelming nature of her downfall.

deliberation: The verse describes desolated towns, desert and steppe, and total absence of inhabitants. This is vivid but straightforward ruin language; no specific metaphor or simile beyond literal description.

God will 'deal with Bel' and 'bring out of his mouth what he has swallowed'. Bel (the idol/god) is personified as a devourer that must disgorge his prey/treasures. This is a strong metaphor with personification.

instances.hebrew_text: וּפָקַדְתִּ֨י עַל־בֵּ֜ל בְּבָבֶ֗ל וְהֹצֵאתִ֤י אֶת־בִּלְעוֹ֙ מִפִּ֔יו
instances.english_text: And I will deal with Bel in Babylon, and make him disgorge what he has swallowed from his mouth
target: Bel’s hold over captured peoples/treasures devoted to him
vehicle: a devouring creature swallowing victims or goods, forced to vomit them out
ground: illegitimate possession and control that must be forcibly reversed; inability to retain stolen goods
God’s power to strip the idol of what it 'consumed'
overturning false power
posture: humiliates Bel by depicting him as a creature forced to vomit back what he has taken
instances.explanation: Bel is portrayed as having 'swallowed' what belongs to others; God will make him spit it out, exposing the idol’s supposed power as empty and reversible.

deliberation: God warns His people to flee 'from the burning anger of YHWH'; 'burning anger' (חֲרוֹן אַף) is a conventional metaphor picturing wrath as heat. That is a clear figurative expression.

instances.english_text: From GOD’s furious [burning] anger
target: the intensity of God’s wrath against Babylon and those who remain
divine emotional state expressed in judgment
vehicle: burning heat, flaring of the nose/face
ground: searing intensity, consuming, destructive force
vehemence and danger of God’s anger
intensity/destructiveness
posture: warns that God’s wrath is dangerously intense, something one must escape like a fire
instances.explanation: God’s wrath is portrayed as burning heat ('fury of His nose'), an idiomatic metaphor stressing its consuming intensity.

deliberation: Talks about rumors, violence, and ruler against ruler in successive years. While 'rumor' is abstract, the language is literal and descriptive, not cast as a separate figure of speech.
God will punish idols and the whole land will 'be ashamed' (תֵּב֑וֹשׁ). 'Land' here stands for its people and is said to feel shame, which is personification combined with metonymy.

instances.english_text: Her whole land shall be shamed
ground: feeling disgraced and humiliated
Babylon’s people deeply humiliated by God’s judgment on their idols
disgrace/shame
posture: emphasizes the moral humiliation of Babylon along with physical ruin
instances.explanation: The 'land' stands for its inhabitants, who are depicted as feeling shame, personifying the territory to describe the people’s humiliation.

deliberation: Heaven and earth and all that is in them are said to 'shout/sing' over Babylon. This personifies the entire cosmos rejoicing at her downfall, a common prophetic image.

instances.hebrew_text: וְרִנְּנ֤וּ עַל־בָּבֶל֙ שָׁמַ֣יִם וָאָ֔רֶץ וְכֹ֖ל אֲשֶׁ֣ר בָּהֶ֑ם
instances.english_text: Heavens and earth and all that is in them shall shout over Babylon
target: the universal response to Babylon’s fall
vehicle: heaven, earth, and all creatures singing or shouting joyfully
ground: universal rejoicing and relief at the removal of a tyrant
cosmic endorsement of God’s judgment
joy/approval
posture: portrays Babylon’s fall as so just that all creation celebrates it
instances.explanation: The entire cosmos is personified as rejoicing over Babylon’s downfall, underscoring that her judgment is universally right and welcome.

deliberation: The syntax is compressed but essentially states that Babylon falls because of the slain of Israel, just as she caused slain in all the earth. No independent figurative image beyond a tight causal statement.

Two idiomatic/metonymic elements: (1) 'fugitives from the sword' uses 'sword' for warfare/death; (2) 'Jerusalem shall come up on your heart' is idiom for remembering thoughtfully. I focus on the clearer metonymy 'from the sword' as one instance.

instances.english_text: You fugitives from the sword
vehicle: the sword as the instrument of killing
weapon standing for battle and death
ground: the sword represents lethal combat and threat of death
those who escaped being killed in war
survival from lethal danger
posture: addresses survivors as people who have narrowly escaped death in war
instances.explanation: The 'sword' stands metonymically for warfare and death, so 'fugitives from the sword' are those who have escaped death in battle.

deliberation: The people say, 'Humiliation covered our faces'—shame is conceptualized as a garment or substance that covers, an idiomatic metaphor; the rest (hearing reproach, foreigners in the sanctuary) is literal.

instances.english_text: Humiliation covered our faces
target: the people’s emotional experience of shame
vehicle: a covering or garment over the face
ground: being visibly and thoroughly overwhelmed by shame, unable to show one’s face
total public humiliation
disgrace/exposure
posture: expresses deep emotional pain at the desecration of God’s house
instances.explanation: Shame is depicted as a covering that envelopes their faces, conveying how completely they feel humiliated.

deliberation: God will punish her images and the slain will groan throughout her land. This is straightforward: idols and mortally wounded; no additional figurative device beyond earlier idol-punishment imagery.

States that even if Babylon climbed to heaven and fortified her stronghold up to the heights, ravagers would still come from God. This uses hyperbolic vertical imagery (ascending to heaven) to express pride and imagined invincibility.

instances.hebrew_text: כִּֽי־תַעֲלֶ֤ה בָבֶל֙ הַשָּׁמַ֔יִם וְכִ֥י תְבַצֵּ֖ר מְר֣וֹם עֻזָּ֑הּ
instances.english_text: Though Babylon should climb to the skies, though she fortify her strongholds up to heaven
target: Babylon’s efforts to secure herself and her pride in security
vehicle: ascending to heaven and fortifying high places
climbing to the sky with strongholds
ground: reaching the highest possible point to be out of danger; extreme self-elevation
Babylon’s imagined invulnerability and arrogance
exaltation/security
posture: ridicules Babylon’s pride, affirming that God’s judgment reaches even the highest heights
instances.explanation: Babylon’s self-secure pride is hyperbolically portrayed as climbing to heaven and fortifying there, yet God still sends ravagers, showing that no height can escape His judgment.

deliberation: Speaks of an outcry from Babylon and great destruction from Chaldea; these are literal references to sounds and ruin. No distinct metaphor or simile.

God is said to silence Babylon’s 'great voice', and their tumult 'roars like many waters'. This uses simile comparing the city’s uproar to mighty waters; the 'voice' of Babylon is also personification of the city’s noise.

instances.hebrew_text: וְאִבַּ֥ד מִמֶּ֖נָּה ק֣וֹל גָּד֑וֹל וְהָמ֤וּ גַלֵּיהֶם֙ כְּמַ֣יִם רַבִּ֔ים
instances.english_text: He will put an end to her great din, whose roar is like waves of mighty waters
ground: loud, continuous, overwhelming sound and force
Babylon’s tumultuous, imposing presence before God silences it
power/tumult
posture: shows that even Babylon’s mighty, sea-like roar will be silenced by God
instances.explanation: Babylon’s great noise is compared to the roar of many waters, emphasizing her powerful tumult, which God will nevertheless bring to an end.

deliberation: A ravager comes on Babylon; warriors are captured; bows broken; and God is called 'a God of requital'. This is judicial epithet, not a distinct metaphor; the images of capture and broken bows are literal war outcomes.

Repeats earlier imagery: God makes officials drunk and they 'sleep an endless sleep, never to awaken'. This again uses drunkenness for stupefaction and eternal sleep as metaphor for irrevocable death. I treat it as one condensed metaphor here, focused on the 'endless sleep' phrase.

instances.english_text: And they shall sleep an endless sleep, never to awaken
ground: inactivity and unresponsiveness as an image for permanent death; contrast with ordinary waking
irreversibility of God’s judgment-death
finality/cessation
posture: presents their demise as absolute and irreversible, underlining the seriousness of God’s sentence
instances.explanation: The leaders’ death is depicted as an 'endless sleep,' stressing that they will never rise again from the judgment God inflicts.

deliberation: After describing the walls and gates literally destroyed, the verse says, 'Peoples shall labor for nothing, and nations for fire, and they will weary themselves.' 'For fire' metaphorically indicates that their labor ends in what will be burned up—futile work whose product is consumed.

instances.hebrew_text: וְיִֽגְע֨וּ עַמִּ֧ים בְּדֵי־רִ֛יק וּלְאֻמִּ֥ים בְּדֵי־אֵ֖שׁ וְיָעֵֽפוּ
instances.english_text: Peoples shall labor for naught, and nations for fire, and they shall weary themselves
target: the efforts of nations in building and supporting Babylon
vehicle: working only to feed the fire (labor 'for fire')
producing something destined immediately to be burned
ground: futility of toiling for what will be destroyed; wasted effort
all their work for Babylon ends in fiery ruin
vanity/futility
posture: declares all imperial-building efforts ultimately futile under God’s judgment
instances.explanation: Nations are said to labor 'for fire', portraying their work as producing what will only be burned, emphasizing the futility of building up doomed Babylon.

deliberation: Historical narrative note about Jeremiah’s command to Seraiah; language is straightforwardly descriptive with no figurative expressions.
Describes Jeremiah writing the disaster into a scroll. This is literal narration; the 'evil' that will come is conceptual but not an image here.
Jeremiah instructs Seraiah to read all these words upon arriving in Babylon. The action and language are literal, not figurative.

Affirms that Babylon will be cut off, without human or animal inhabitant, a desolation forever. This is formulaic ruin language but not framed as an explicit simile or metaphor beyond standard prophetic hyperbole.

Commands tying a stone to the scroll and throwing it into the Euphrates. The act is symbolic and will be interpreted in v.64, but in this verse the wording is purely instructional; the figurative meaning is not yet stated here.

Explains the symbolic act: 'Thus shall Babylon sink and not rise again.' This is a metaphor: Babylon’s political downfall is likened to an object sinking irretrievably in a river, corresponding to the scroll with a stone.

instances.english_text: Thus shall Babylon sink and never rise again
target: Babylon’s final overthrow as an empire
vehicle: an object sinking into deep water and not rising
stone-bound scroll submerged in a river
ground: irrevocable submergence, disappearance from sight, impossibility of self-recovery
Babylon’s irreversible collapse under divine judgment
final loss/irreversibility
posture: emphatically declares the finality of Babylon’s fall to reassure hearers of its certainty
instances.explanation: Babylon’s downfall is portrayed as a sinking object that will never rise again, interpreting the symbolic act of casting the weighted scroll into the Euphrates as a sign of her irreversible ruin.
